abstract.p: Jake Sherman letter on Oct 24 article questions Thomas L Friedman's view that China is moving toward global economy and away from conflict in light of study showing over million people in China are involved in organized criminal activities

block.p: Thomas L. Friedman (column, Oct. 24) suggests that the world is characterized by two major forces: a dominant flow ''toward more integration, networking and the global economy'' and a simultaneous undertow in the opposite direction toward conflict.
In reality, the trends Mr. Friedman identifies are often symbiotic; greater integration and networking may be accompanied by illicit global trade networks that contribute to crime and conflict.

Thomas L. Friedman (column, Oct. 24) suggests that the world is characterized by two major forces: a dominant flow ''toward more integration, networking and the global economy'' and a simultaneous undertow in the opposite direction toward conflict.
In reality, the trends Mr. Friedman identifies are often symbiotic; greater integration and networking may be accompanied by illicit global trade networks that contribute to crime and conflict.

Mr. Friedman's characterization of China as having decided ''to go with the dominant flow'' is paradoxical given a Nanjing University study, as reported by the BBC, that said more than a million people in China are involved in organized criminal activities, including drug trafficking, selling women and the smuggling of Chinese migrants out of China.
